instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message:
This board had a small amount of liquid damage around the SMC area and in that area on the other side of the board I replaced several components around that area and have ultrasonic'd the board. 
Initially I started by replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q5030</TRANSISTOR>/50, R/<CAPACITOR>C5329</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4901</CAPACITOR>/20, <RESISTOR>R5488</RESISTOR>/89, <CAPACITOR>C5489</CAPACITOR>
C/<CHIP>U6901</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR>, <CHIP>U7780</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R2460</RESISTOR>/65, <CAPACITOR>C7781</CAPACITOR>
After replacing all those the board was just pulsing and not turning on. I then replaced <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> and then the board started turning on and the heatsink got warm.

After assembling there was no chime or video on the screen but the fan spun and I was able to turn the machine on and off with the keyboard. I did an SMC and PRAM reset but that didn't help.

I measured <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> but I only get about 0.017v.

The entire <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> area is spotless and <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/03 measure the proper resistance  and that is from the resistor to the pin on the chip so I made sure the traces are fine.
<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> Measurements
Pin 1 - 0.53v
Pin 48 - 0.64v
Pin 47 - 3.29v
Pins 46, 29, 19 - 5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message:
Hi ytesfay80, 
​​​​​​I have the same exact issue with the same board, i'm suspecting the smc. 
Do you have <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and DDRVTT rails ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message:
I only get 0.13v on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and 0v on <SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>.
I figure it might be an issue with the <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> chip I replaced.  I am only getting 0.9v on both sides of <RESISTOR>R7765</RESISTOR> and 0.6v on <CAPACITOR>C7764</CAPACITOR>. I tried putting 2 other <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> chips from donor boards but the fan wouldn't even turn on and the cpu didn't get warm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message:
I don't understand why you're looking at <CHIP>U7760</CHIP>, this one is only providing <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_REG</SIGNAL>, do you have that rail?
In my case also the CPU is not getting hot ( normal : it's not powered)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message:
For some reason when I measured <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> on <CAPACITOR>C7780</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C7762</CAPACITOR> and get 3.28v.
On <RESISTOR>R7760</RESISTOR> I get 3.26v on Pin 1 and 1.09v on Pin 2. Not sure but these measurements don't seem like what they should be.

I get 0.75v on <SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL> but 0v on <SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> all have the proper voltage on them so it looks like the 1V8 rail is the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> should be present before you even worry about PPVCORE. There must be a rail missing that is keeping <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> low. If <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_REG</SIGNAL> is not present then that will at least be a problem!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message:
I am getting 3.28v on <CAPACITOR>C7780</CAPACITOR>(<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>). 
Do you know why it would be so high when it should be 1.8v? Could it be due to the <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> chip I put on? I didn't have a stencil to reball that chip so I just put solder on the pads and flowed it onto the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message: 3V on 1.8V line is NOT good. Yes of course the problem is a fucked <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> and now the board is possibly totally fried. Pull of <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> and put balls on the board then put a clean <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> from a donor on the balls and pray that the whole thing did not fry with the 3V fuck up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message:
Okay I replaced <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> with a new one from digi-key(MAX15053EWL+T) and now I has no fan spin and the 5v/3v3 S3 and S0 rails are missing. I checked for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> but there is only a quick pulse when the charger plugged in and then 0v afterwards.

The <SIGNAL>1V8_S0</SIGNAL> line is not shorted to ground in diode mode.
<SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>1V8_S0</SIGNAL> is no longer connected to each other.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message: I'm pretty sure you already killed the CPU or PCH by sending 3V to the 1.8V rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
threads.message:
I removed that chip again from the board and cleaned the pads and now I'm getting a quarter fan spin that keeps trying to turn on every 5 seconds.

Can someone take a picture of the positioning of the <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> chip on a donor board so I can make sure I am putting this new chip facing the right direction because I don't see any dot on the chip that marks where pin 1 is?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spins but no chime or vcore
